As one of the most important industrially viable methods for carbon dioxide (CO2) utilization, methanol synthesis serves as a platform for production of green fuels and commodity chemicals. For sustainable methanol synthesis, In2O3 is an ideal catalyst and has garnered significant attention. Herein, cubic In2O3 nanoparticles were prepared via the precipitation method and evaluated for CO2 hydrogenation to produce methanol. During the initial 10 h of reaction, CO2 conversion gradually increased, accompanied by a slow decrease of methanol selectivity, and the reaction reached equilibrium after 10-20 h on stream. This activation and induction stage may be attributed to the sintering of In2O3 nanoparticles and the creation of more oxygen vacancies on In2O3 surfaces. Further experimental studies demonstrate that hydrogen induction created additional oxygen vacancies during the catalyst activation stage, enhancing the performance of In2O3 catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation. Density functional theory calculations and microkinetic simulations further demonstrated that surfaces with higher oxygen vacancy coverages or hydroxylated surfaces formed during this induction period can enhance the reaction rate and increase the CO2 conversion. However, they predominantly promote the formation of CO instead of methanol, leading to reduced methanol selectivity. These predictions align well with the above-mentioned experimental observations. Our work thus provides an in-depth analysis of the induction stage of the CO2 hydrogenation process on In2O3 nano-catalyst, and offers valuable insights for significantly improving the CO2 reactivity of In2O3-based catalysts while maintaining long-term stability. Graphical Abstract During the induction period of the In2O3 catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation, the CO2 conversion rate was found to increase as the active surface was hydroxylated to reach a higher oxygen vacancy coverage, and such structural change was revealed to promote CO formation more than methanol formation, resulting in the decline of methanol selectivity during this period of reaction. Keywords In2O3CO2 hydrogenation Methanol production Induction and activation Structural evolution 1 Introduction Replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy is one of the greatest challenges in the 21st century [1–4]. To achieve net zero carbon emission by 2050, renewable energy production will need to increase by 6 to 8 times with respect to its current level [5]. Using CO2 as a widely available, inexpensive, non-toxic, and harmless carbon source, combining it with green hydrogen under the assistance of catalysts to produce bulk chemicals and liquid fuels (e.g. methanol) [6–10] has enormous potential for realizing the carbon cycling and recovery [11–14]. The impact of the “methanol economy” proposed by Olah [15] will become more prominent in the coming years, potentially ushering in a new era of fuel production. By designing and tuning the structure, composition, and surface properties of catalysts, it is possible to enhance the long-term stability of catalysts while improving the CO2 conversion rate and methanol selectivity, thus achieving efficient, sustainable, and economically viable production of green methanol [16–18]. Indium oxide (In2O3) catalysts have broad application prospects for methanol production through thermochemical CO2 hydrogenation [19,20]. In2O3 is an n-type semiconductor material with a relatively large band gap (E g: 3.5–3.7 eV). The crystal structure of In2O3 is dominated by ionic bonds while also exhibiting significant covalent interactions between indium (In) and oxygen (O), whose coordination numbers are 6 and 4, respectively [21]. In2O3 has two predominant polymorphs, cubic phase In2O3 (bixbyite type, c-In2O3) and hexagonal phase In2O3 (corundum type, h-In2O3) [22], and the crystal facets and lattice distances of the In2O3 catalyst can be tuned by varying the In precursor and synthesis method (including thermally and chemically induced phase transition), which can lead to significantly different catalytic performance [22–24]. In2O3 nanoparticles (NPs) possess various tunable morphologies with very high specific surface areas, along with relatively low formation energies for the surface oxygen vacancies. These characteristics endow In2O3 with immense potential in fields such as gas sensors, biosensors, and photo/thermos catalysis [25,26]. For CO2 hydrogenation between 200–300 °C, the methanol selectivity over the In2O3 catalyst can reach 100%. However, the actual space‐time yield (STY) of methanol remains relatively low, and does not meet the requirement of industry applications, so higher performance In2O3 catalysts are necessary for their applications to the CO2 hydrogenation reactions [27]. Extensive density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed to understand the catalytic mechanism of methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation [28–31]. Ye et al. [32] revealed the significant role of oxygen vacancies on the In2O3 (110) surface for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol using periodic DFT calculations. Frei et al. [33], who evaluated the CO2 hydrogenation performance, and found that the apparent activation energy of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over the In2O3 catalyst (E a = 103 kJ mol−1) was noticeably lower than that of the RWGS reaction (E a = 117 kJ mol−1). Müller et al. [3] further demonstrated through in-situ experiments that excessive reduction of the In2O3 catalyst to metallic In0 could lead to catalyst deactivation. DFT calculations from our group found that the three-coordinated oxygen vacancies on the c-In2O3 (111) and h-In2O3 (104) surfaces were more favorable for methanol formation than the two-coordinated oxygen vacancy sites on the c-In2O3 (110) and h-In2O3 (012) surfaces, and we further prepared different In2O3 materials, including c‐In2O3 nanoplates, h‐In2O3 nano lamellar particles, and h‐In2O3 nanorods, and the highest activity and methanol selectivity (73.4%) were achieved with the h‐In2O3 nanorods predominantly exposing the (104) surfaces, and the STY of methanol reached 10.9 mmol gcat −1 h−1 at 360 °C [24]. Most previous theoretical studies on In2O3 used models with only a single surface oxygen vacancy (VO) per unit cell, resulting in a relatively low VO coverage of < 0.1 ML. However, recent experimental studies have shown that a hydrogen-rich atmosphere was observed near the VO sites, where H atoms might combine with O atoms to form OH, and a higher oxygen vacancy coverage on the In2O3 surface could be reached due to hydrogen reduction [3,34]. Posada-Borbón et al. [35] investigated the CO2 reactivity of hydroxylated In2O3 (110) surfaces with 83% hydrogen coverage using DFT-based microkinetic simulations, and they also proposed the In2O3 (111) surface with 33% H coverage to be the most stable under hydroxylated conditions from thermodynamic calculations [36]. Smaller In2O3 crystals have been found to exhibit higher initial activity for CO2 and H2 activations, which may be attributed to their higher specific surface area and more numerous surface defect sites. However, compared with particles of other sizes, In2O3 particles of 19 nm were more beneficial to the formation of methanol intermediates, as smaller particles were less stable due to sintering [20]. Although larger In2O3 nanoparticles have lower initial activity, they are less prone to over-reduction [37]. Previous studies also attempted to improve the structural stability of In2O3 nanoparticles to enhance the catalytic performance for CO2 hydrogenation [38]. Although substantial progress has been made in researches on In2O3-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [39–46], understanding the structure-activity relationships and developing more efficient In2O3-based catalysts require a better understanding of the evolution of active sites under realistic reaction conditions [3,47,48]. In this study, we aim to capture the evolution of the active site at the initial stage, and compare it with the structure at the stable stage, which is realized by a combination of experimental studies, DFT calculations, and microkinetic simulations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Cubic indium oxide nanoparticles were prepared via the precipitation method. 10.0 g In(NO3)3·4.5 H2O were dissolved into a mixture of 100 mL deionized water and 100 mL anhydrous ethanol. After the solid was completely dissolved, 30 mL of 1.5 mol L−1 (NH4)2CO3 solution was added to the above mixed salt solution dropwise, and the precipitate was then stirred vigorously for 5 min. The slurry formed was aged at 60 °C for 30 min. Afterwards, the precipitate was filtrated and washed with deionized water, and the so-obtained solid sample was then dried at 80 °C followed by calcination in air at 300 °C for 3 h with a ramping rate of 2 °C min−1. 2.2 Catalyst evaluation CO2 hydrogenation was performed in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor. The catalyst (0.5 g) and the same volume of quartz sand were evenly mixed and packed in the reactor. Prior to the test, the reactor with catalyst was heated with Ar (60 mL min−1) for 1 h at 300 °C. The unit was then cooled down naturally to 200 °C. The reactant mixture (H2/CO2/N2 = 72:24:4) was then introduced into the reactor until the pressure reached 5 MPa. The unit was ramped up from 200 to 300 °C at 5 °C min−1. The gaseous hourly space velocity (GHSV) was adjusted to 7200 mL h−1 gcat −1. The conversion rate of carbon dioxide (X(CO2)), the selectivities of carbon monoxide (S(CO)), methane (S(CH4)), methanol (S(CH3OH)), and the space‐time yield of methanol (STY(CH3OH)) were calculated using the following equations: (1) X(CO2) = (CO2(inlet) – CO2(outlet))/CO2(inlet) (2) S(CO) = COoutlet/(CO2inlet – CO2outlet) × 100% (3) S(CH4) = CH4outlet/(CO2inlet – CO2outlet) × 100% (4) S(CH3OH) = CH4outlet/(CO2inlet – CO2outlet) × 100% (5) STY(CH3OH)) = GHSV × V %(CO2) × X(CO2) × S(CH3OH) × M(CH3OH)/(22.4 × 1000 × m cat) [g gcat −1 h−1] 2.3 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray powder diffractometer with copper Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å), operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. Cu Ka radiation (k = 51.540589 Å) was used for a continuous scanning over a 2θ range of 10°−90° at a scanning speed of 4°/min. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were obtained on a JEOL-JEM 2011 electron microscope (200 kV). The as-prepared catalyst sample was ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol, and then dried on a carbon-coated copper grid. The size distribution of each sample was estimated based on data from 150 particles. N2 physisorption experiments were carried out on a Micromeritics 2020 instrument at −196 °C. The Brunauer-Emmett-Tellwer (BET) method was used to calculate the specific surface areas. Pore volume and pore size were determined by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on a Thermo Scientific K-α spectrometer using Al Kα X-rays (150 W, hm = 1486.6 eV) under ultrahigh vacuum (5 × 10–7 bar). The binding energies (BEs) were calibrated using C 1s peak at 284.8 eV as a reference. Temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) for samples were performed using a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2920. Approximately 100 mg of sample was first pretreated with high-purity Ar flow for 1 h at 150 °C. After the pretreatment, the gas mixture (5% H2/Ar) was introduced into the tube at a rate of 40 mL min−1 at 50 °C. Thereafter, the temperature was increased from 50 to 750 °C at a linear heating rate of 5 °C min−1. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) experiments were carried out with a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2920. First, the catalyst (0.1 g) was pretreated at 300 °C for 60 min in a flow of pure Ar of 40 mL min−1 and then cooled to 50 °C or without any pretreatment. Afterwards, the catalyst was saturated in flowing CO2 for 1 h at 40 mL min−1 and followed by flushing in Ar for 1 h to remove any physisorbed molecules. The CO2-TPD measurement was then carried out between 50–750 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under continuous flow of Ar at 40 mL min−1. Raman spectra were collected in the range of 100–700 cm−1 on the Thermo DVR2xi Raman Spectrometer excited with a 532 nm laser source at a resolution of within 1 cm−1. The laser power was set to 7 mW, and the integration time was 5 s. 2.4 Theoretical calculations 2.4.1 DFT calculations All periodic DFT calculations were carried out with the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [49,50] using Bayesian error estimation functional with van der Waals correlation (BEEF-VDW) [51] exchange-correlation functional and the projector-augmented wave potentials [52]. An energy cut-off of 400 eV, and a force convergence of 0.03 eV Å−1 on all unconstrained atoms were enforced. Gaussian smearing with a smearing width of 0.05 eV was used, and the electronic energy of the supercell was converged to 10−4 eV. Transition state (TS) structures were located using the nudged elastic band (NEB) method [53]. The initial images were generated using the Image Dependent Pair Potential procedure implemented in the Atomic Simulation Environment (ASE) package [54]. The cubic In2O3 (c-In2O3) (110) and (111) surfaces were built from the optimized primitive unit cell (PUC) with lattice parameters of a =10.21 Å, b = 14.44 Å and c = 15.99 Å. The In2O3 (110) surface was modeled by a rectangular p(1×√2) supercell with four repeated layers, and was optimized using a Г-centered Monkhorst-Pack (4 × 3 × 1) k-point mesh [55]. The In2O3 (111) surface was modeled by a p(1 × 1) supercell with three repeated layers, and was optimized using a Г-centered Monkhorst-Pack (3 × 3 × 1) k-point mesh. V O formation energy refers to the energy required to generate a specific V O site on a given surface, and can be calculated from the following equation: (6) Δ E f,V o = E V o + 1 2 E O 2 - E Surface Here, E VO is the energy of the surface with the specified VO site, E O2 is the energy of an isolated O2 molecule, and E Surface is the energy of the surface before the formation of the specific VO. The energy barrier (E a) of an elementary reaction, for example, direct CO2 dissociation to CO or CO2 hydrogenation to HCOO*, can be calculated from the following equation: (7) E a = E TS – E IS Here, E TS and E IS are the energies of the transition state and the initial state, respectively. 2.4.2 Microkinetic simulations CatMAP [56] was used to simulate the reaction kinetics of CH3OH and CO formations from CO2 hydrogenation under the typical experimental reaction conditions of 200–400 °C and 5 MPa. The enthalpies and entropies of gaseous species were calculated using the ideal gas model, while those of the surface adsorbates and the transition states were obtained using the harmonic approximation. The degrees of rate control (DRC) proposed by Campbell and co-workers [57–60] of the different transition states for CO2 consumption were calculated using the implementation inside CatMAP, which represents the control degree of each primitive reaction on the whole reaction. The DRC value is a better indicator of the rate-determining step than the relative size of the energy barrier, as it can also account for other factors such as the reaction conditions and the overall energy profiles. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Performance of the In2O3 catalyst in CO2 hydrogenation In2O3 catalysts were prepared by the precipitation method, and were pretreated in an Ar flow at 300 °C for 1 h prior to CO2 hydrogenation tests at 220–300 °C and 1–5 MPa. During the CO2 hydrogenation reaction over the evaluated catalysts, methanol and CO were always detected as the predominant products, whereas the amount of methane produced was negligible. Between 220–300 °C, the reactions were under the kinetic-controlled regime, the CO2 conversion and the methanol space‐time yield increased as the reaction pressure and temperature increased (Fig. 1 ). The increase of reaction pressure improved the methanol selectivity and limited the CO selectivity (Fig. 1(a)). The selectivities of methanol and CO for all of the samples follow the same trend, i.e. the methanol selectivity decreases while CO selectivity increases with increasing reaction temperature due to the exothermic nature of the methanol synthesis reaction and the endothermic nature of the RWGS reaction. (Fig. 1(b)). Results of the catalytic performance tests were collected in Table S1. As shown in Fig. 1 and Table S1, the In2O3 catalyst exhibits the highest methanol space‐time yield (0.107 gMeOH gcat −1 h−1) at the reaction temperature of 300 °C under the pressure of 5 MPa, where the CO2 conversion reaches to 8.2% with a methanol selectivity of 52.5%. During the 60 h performance test at 300 °C under 5 MPa (Fig. 1(c)), the In2O3 catalyst exhibits a gradual increase in catalytic activity but a gradual decrease in methanol selectivity in the first 10 h of the reaction, and the evolution in the performance gradually stabilizes within 10−20 h. Between 20−60 h, the CO2 conversion, the methanol selectivity, and the methanol space‐time yield were maintained at ~8% ~55%, and ~0.1 gMeOH gcat −1 h−1, respectively. It is obvious that before arriving at the stable stage of the reaction, there is an activation stage during the initial stage. Without Ar pretreatment, this induction period was even longer (Fig. S1). To understand this induction period of the reaction, it is important to reveal the active site and structural evolution of In2O3 catalyst, in order to guide the design and synthesis of higher performance In2O3 catalysts and improve their activity and stability for CO2 hydrogenation. Different characterizations were applied in the following sections to identify the reasons for the performance changes in this activation stage. 3.2 Characterizations Multiple characterization methods were used to analyze the chemical state of In2O3 with different situations (fresh, Ar, 1, 5, 10, 20, 40 h), where Ar means the catalyst pretreated in an Ar atmosphere at 300 °C for 1 h, x h means the catalyst spent under the reaction condition for x h. The XRD patterns of In2O3 catalysts with different situations are presented in Fig. 2 . Only the peaks of the cubic In2O3 crystalline lattice can be identified for all the catalysts tested. The characteristic peaks appearing at 21.5°, 30.6°, 35.5°, 45.7°, 51.0°, and 60.7° can be ascribed to the cubic structure of (211), (222), (400), (431), (440) and (622), respectively, according to PDF#06-0416 [61]. The average crystallite size of the catalysts is estimated using the Scherrer equation and shown in Table S2. Zooming in the (222) characteristic peak reveals a narrowing of the peak after Ar pretreatment and a further narrowing of the peak between 1 h and 5 h of the reaction, after which the half-peak width of the catalyst and the grain size are essentially unchanged. At around 30.6°, the (222) peak first moves towards a lower angle during the reaction, and then returns to its original position, which may be due to lattice distortion caused by the reduction and formation of oxygen vacancies on indium oxide during the reaction. The particle size distribution of the catalysts was characterized by TEM as shown in Fig. 3 . Compared with the fresh catalyst (7.1 nm particles, Fig. 3(a)), the average particle size of the catalysts increases to 15.1 nm (Fig. 3(b)) within the first hour of reaction, and the catalyst particles grow up to 18.1 nm (Fig. 3(c)) and 20.1 nm (Fig. 3(d)) after 5 and 10 h of reaction, respectively. As shown in Figs. 3(e) and 3(f), the average size of the catalysts after reaction of 20 and 40 h are 20.7 and 20.4 nm, respectively. The size distribution derived from TEM images is in good agreement with the XRD results in Table S2. Obviously, the sintering of In2O3 nanoparticles occurs at the initial stage in the feeding gas at 300 °C, especially in the first hour of the reaction. From 10 to 20 h, the size distribution shifted slowly to the larger particle size, and after 20 h, there were no longer any obvious changes in the catalyst morphology, and the average size of the particles remained at around 20 nm, reaching a relatively stable state for the In2O3 catalysts. As shown in Fig. S2 for the HR-TEM images of In2O3 under various conditions, all the samples exhibit the typical cubic-In2O3 lattice fringes with a d-spacing of about 0.29 nm at multiple locations, corresponding to the (222) plane of In2O3 (a multiple of the (111) plane). This observation suggests that the exposed (111) surface was stable during the reaction. Figs. 4(a) and (b) show the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the pore size distributions of In2O3 under different situations, and Table 1 collects the texture properties of these samples. The fresh sample has a remarkably high BET surface area of 129 m2 g–1, and possesses a type IV adsorption isotherm with a H1 hysteresis loop, indicating a narrow pore size distribution, which can be attributed to the relative uniform size of the fresh In2O3 particles with spherical aggregation [62]. We note that all the specific surface areas of the reacted catalysts are significantly lower compared to that of the fresh catalyst. All the spent samples possess the type III adsorption isotherms without hysteresis loops, and their pore widths increase and their BET surface areas decrease to 28–37 m2 g–1, demonstrating the sintering of the catalyst during the reaction, which occurs very rapidly and is clearly observed within the first hour of reaction. As suggested by a previous study, oxygen vacancies can facilitate the adsorption and subsequent activation of CO2, allowing CO2-TPD to be employed to study the surface oxygen vacancies of In2O3 [63]. Fig. 4(c) collects the CO2-TPD profiles for In2O3 under various conditions. The peak in region I at around 120 °C can be ascribed to the physically adsorbed CO2. There is no peak in the fresh catalyst after Ar processing at region II (200–350 °C), while this peak appears in the spent catalysts, suggesting that this peak might correspond to the CO2 adsorbed on the hydrogen-induced oxygen vacancy. Thus, these results indicate the appearance of hydrogen-induced oxygen vacancy within the first hour in the feed gas flow at 300 °C, which is the dominant type of oxygen vacancy. The intensity of the peak in region III (350–700 °C) of catalysts pretreated in Ar at 300 °C (Fig. S3) is significantly higher than that without any pretreatment in Fig. 4(c), suggesting that peak III might correspond to the CO2 adsorbed on the thermally induced vacancy. Furthermore, results from the quantitative analysis of Fig. 4(c) and Fig. S3 are collected in Table S3, and the higher ratio of thermal-induced oxygen vacancy for the Ar-pretreated In2O3 catalyst led to the strengthening of CO2 adsorption. To investigate the reduction behavior of catalysts, H2-TPR was carried out, and the resultant profiles are shown in Fig. 4(d). For the pristine In2O3 pretreated in Ar at 300 °C for 1 h, the reduction peak at around 180 °C can be ascribed to the reduction of surface In2O3, corresponding to the formation of hydrogen-induced vacancy on the surface [34,64,65]. On the contrary, the intensity of this peak for the spent catalysts decreases significantly and moves towards high temperature. This indicates that hydrogen-induced oxygen vacancies are immediately formed during the first hour of the reaction process, consistent with the conclusions from the CO2-TPD characterization. Raman spectroscopy has been employed to provide direct spectroscopic evidence for the presence of oxygen vacancies in In2O3 [66]. In the present study, the catalysts were analyzed using room temperature-visible Raman scattering to probe the oxygen vacancies in In2O3, as shown in Fig. 5(a) . The peak at 131 cm–1 is assigned to the In–O vibration of the InO6 structural unit. The peak at 304 cm–1 is attributed to the bending vibration of the InO6 octahedrons. The peaks at 493 and 630 cm–1 are usually interpreted as the stretching vibrations of the octahedral InO6 in In2O3. The peak at 364 cm–1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of In-O-In (ν(In-O-In)), which reflects the presence of oxygen vacancies in In2O3 [67,68]. The intensity of the peak at 364 cm–1 is positively correlated with the increase in the oxygen vacancy content in In2O3. As the peak at 304 cm–1 represents the InO6 octahedrons, which is relatively constant for all the samples, it can be chosen as the reference peak for the normalization. To quantify the amounts of the oxygen vacancies for the different catalysts, we integrated the peak at 304 cm–1 (I 1) and 364 cm–1 (I 2), and used the I 2/I 1 ratio to characterize the amount of the oxygen vacancies in In2O3 [69,70]. As shown in the inset of Fig. 5(a), a significant increase in the oxygen vacancy content occurs after pretreatment of the fresh catalyst with Ar, which may be caused by an increase in thermally induced oxygen vacancy content due to heat treatment. After the reaction, a further increase in the oxygen vacancy content was observed, which originated from the reduction of In2O3 by hydrogen in the feed gas. Within the first hour, it led to a significant increase in the amount of hydrogen-induced oxygen vacancies in In2O3, followed by a gradual increase of oxygen vacancies over the next 5 h. Between 10–20 h, the oxygen vacancy content observed by the XPS was relatively stable, while the moderate increase of hydrogen-induced oxygen vacancies on the subsurface may proceed consistently. XPS was further used to analyze the chemical states of the surface O atoms on In2O3 with different situations, as shown by the O 1s core level spectra in Fig. 5(b), which can be deconvoluted into three major peaks for In2O3. The peak at 529.6 eV is assigned to the lattice oxygen (Olattice), and a second peak at 530.4 eV corresponds to the oxygen defect sites (Odefect) in metal oxides [71,72]. An extra peak at a higher binding energy (ca. 531.9 eV) can be attributed to the hydroxyl (OH) absorbate species on the catalyst surface (OAds.*OH) [73]. This peak shifts slightly after the reaction, which might be caused by the OH originated from the produced methanol. Generally, the relative concentration of oxygen vacancies (C Odefect) can be assessed by calculating the ratio between the area of the characteristic peak (C Odefect = A Odefect/(A Odefect + A Olattice + AoAds.*OH)), where A is the area of the characteristic peak) [69]. The relative concentration of oxygen vacancies (C Odefect) and the area percentages of the three types of oxygen are collected in Table S4. The slight increase in the oxygen vacancy content after Ar pretreatment and its further increase as the reaction time increases are consistent with results from the Raman spectra (Fig. 5(a)). The full survey XPS was collected in Fig. S4(a), and the valence state of indium under various conditions was found to be In3+ as shown in Figs. S4(b,c). 3.3 DFT calculations In our experiments, we observed that the CO2 conversion rate increased during the induction period of the In2O3-catalyzed CO2 hydrogenation reaction, but the methanol selectivity decreased. We speculate that there might be significant changes in the structure of the catalyst surface, which greatly impacts the catalytic performance. To rationalize the above experimental observations, we studied the catalytic activity of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol and CO on different model surfaces through DFT calculations and microkinetic simulations. Compared to the stoichiometric termination, an oxygen-defective In2O3(110) surface was predicted to have superior performance for methanol synthesis by Ge et al. [29,32] and Yu et al. [74]. Furthermore, the (111) facet was found to be the thermodynamically most stable termination of In2O3 [75]. Frei et al. [33] reported that the In2O3(111) was the most exposed surface termination, the oxygen vacancies surrounded by three indium atoms facilitated CO2 activation and the heterolytic hydrogen splitting, the structural characterization of the In2O3 catalyst confirmed the dominant exposure of the (111) termination. The model surfaces considered in this work include the In2O3 (111) surface with an oxygen vacancy typically used in many previous studies, which is denoted as (111)-one-VO, that with a monolayer of oxygen vacancies denoted as (111)-all-VO, and that with a 33% H-coverage denoted as (111)-33%-H. During CO2 hydrogenation, more oxygen vacancies will be formed from the reduction of hydrogen, and the H atom will be adsorbed at the O atom to form the hydroxyl group after H2 splitting, so the hydroxylated surface is also constructed. For the In2O3 catalyst prepared by the precipitation method in this work, the In2O3 (111) facet was characterized to be the predominantly exposed surface [20]. The top views of these catalyst models are shown in Fig. 6(a) , and their side views and the structure of the perfect catalyst surface are presented in Fig. S5. As shown in Fig. S5 for the In2O3 (111) surface, the VO7 site was usually considered to have the highest reactivity [33,76], and was thus selected as the active site for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. In addition, In2O3 (110) is also an active surface for CO2 hydrogenation a catalyst model with 33% H-coverage on the In2O3 (110) surface denoted as (110)-33%-H was also considered, where the VO4 site previously identified [29,31] to have the highest reactivity was selected as the active site for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The (110)-33%-H surface and the VO4 site can be seen in Fig. S6. The formation energies of VO7 on (111)-one-VO, (111)-all-VO, (111)-33%-H and VO4 on (110)-33%-H were compared. The highest VO formation energy is 3.93 eV for the (111)-33%-H surface, which is followed by 3.29 eV for the (111)-one-VO surface and 3.07 eV for the (110)-33%-H surface, whereas the lowest is 2.57 eV for the (111)-all-VO surface. Figs. 6(b,c) shows the energy profiles of methanol and CO formations, and the structures involved can be seen in Figs. S7 and S8. The reaction pathway of methanol formation on the (110)-33%-H surface is shown in Fig. S9. Many DFT studies have been reported on the reaction pathway of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on the In2O3 surfaces [24,28,29,32,46], and the mechanism of methanol formation shown in the above figures is generally consistent with previous reports [24,32]. Briefly, CO2 is physically adsorbed on the catalyst surface to form ln-CO2*, which is reported to lead to methanol formation [24]. This is followed by ln-CO2* + H_In* → HCOO* → HCOO* + H_In* → H2COO* → H2CO* + O* → H2CO* + H_In* + H_O* → CH3O* + H_O* → CH3OH* + O*. Upon the CH3OH desorption, the oxygen vacancy on the catalyst is filled by an O atom, which can be regenerated by H2 reduction. From Fig. 6(b) and Fig. S9, the overall potential energy profile on the (111)-one-VO surface is lower than those of the (111)-all-VO and (110)-33%-H surfaces, so the effective energy barrier of the (111)-one-VO surface is the lowest. This indicates that the reaction intermediates are stabilized on the (111)-one-VO surface, and the (111)-all-VO and (110)-33%-H surfaces are thermodynamically less conducive to CH3OH formation. From the calculated energy barriers for methanol formation, the rate-determining step (RDS) for the (111)-one-VO surface is HCOO* + H_In* → H2COO* with an energy barrier of 0.58 eV; that on the (111)-all-VO surface is H2CO* + H_In* + H_O* → H3CO* + H_O* with an energy barrier of 1.14 eV; that on the (110)-33%-H surface is HCOO* + H_In* → H2COO* with an energy barrier of 0.64 eV. Thus, the energy barrier of the RDS for the (111)-one-VO surface is the lowest, so the (111)-all-VO and (110)-33%-H surfaces are also kinetically less conducive to methanol formation. Although the potential energy surface of the (111)-33%-H surface is lower than that of the (111)-one-VO surface, reaction intermediates adsorbed on (111)-33%-H are thermodynamically more stable, the energy barrier of its RDS (H2COO* → H2CO*+O*) of 1.54 eV for the former is much higher than that of 0.58 eV for the latter, suggesting the (111)-33%-H surface to be also kinetically unfavorable for methanol formation than the (111)-one-VO surface. In general, CO can form from the direct and indirect dissociations of CO2. In CO2 direct dissociation, adsorbed CO and O are formed on the catalyst surface, whereas in CO2 indirect dissociation, CO2 is first hydrogenated to COOH, which is then followed by COOH dissociation to adsorbed CO and OH. Due to the instability of COOH on the (111)-33%-H, (110)-33%-H and (111)-all-VO surfaces, only CO2 direct dissociation is considered for CO formation for our studied surfaces. Different from methanol formation, CO2 is first chemisorbed to form bt-CO2*, which is conducive to CO formation [24], and its adsorption structure can be seen in Fig. S10. It is generally believed that the higher the oxygen vacancy formation energy, the more favorable for the CO2 chemisorption [28]. The (111)-33%-H surface has the highest oxygen vacancy formation energy, and its CO2 adsorption energy is indeed the most negative at –0.23 eV. The VO formation energy of the (111)-one-VO surface is 0.64 eV lower than that of (111)-33%-H surface, although its CO2 adsorption energy is only slightly less negative at –0.21 eV. The oxygen vacancy formation energy of the (110)-33%-H surface is lower than those of both the (111)-one-VO and (111)-33%-H surfaces, and its CO2 adsorption energy is also quite positive at 0.47 eV. The (111)-all-VO surface has the lowest oxygen vacancy formation energy, and its CO2 adsorption energy is the most positive at 0.99 eV. Thus, for these surfaces, the lower the VO formation energy, the less favorable the CO2 chemisorption. Upon CO formation, the other O atom from the dissociated CO2 fills the oxygen vacancy, which can be regenerated by H2 reduction. The pathway for the RWGS reaction on the (110)-33%-H surface is shown in Fig. S11. From Fig. 6(c), for the CO2 direct dissociation (bt-CO2* → CO*+O*), the energy barrier on the (111)-one-VO surface of 1.42 eV is much higher than those on the (111)-all-VO (0.30 eV), (111)-33%-H (0.58 eV), and (110)-33%-H (0.80 eV) surfaces. Therefore, from a kinetic perspective, the (111)-all-VO, (111)-33%-H, and (110)-33%-H surfaces are all more favorable for CO formation than the (111)-one-VO surface. We note that there is another possible pathway for the RWGS reaction, which is via hydrogen-assisted dissociation and involves the COOH* species. However, on the (111)-all-VO and (111)-33%-H surfaces, the COOH* species is so unstable that the hydrogen-assisted dissociation pathway was predicted to not occur. The oxygen vacancy can be regenerated by heterocleavage of H2 and H2O formation. From Figs. 6(c) and S11, the potential energy surface of oxygen vacancy formation on the (111)-one-VO surface is much higher than that of the (111)-33%-H surface, and the potential energy for the (111)-one-VO surface is similar to those of the (111)-all-VO and (110)-33%-H surfaces. However, for the formation of VO, the (111)-one-VO surface has the highest energy barrier of 1.55 eV, which may limit the overall reaction rate. From the calculated energy profiles and energy barriers, we can conclude that if the catalyst surface has a higher oxygen vacancy coverage or a 33%H covered surface is formed, it will not be conducive to the formation of CH3OH and may instead produce more CO, which provides preliminary evidence to support the experimentally observed decrease in methanol selectivity during the induction period. 3.4 Microkinetic simulations Based on the results of our DFT calculations, we further conducted microkinetic simulations for the reaction. Fig. 7(a) shows the reaction rates of CO2 hydrogenation over the different surfaces. The (111)-one-VO surface (black line) has a lower reaction rate than the other three surfaces by three to five orders of magnitude. From Figs. 6(c) and S11, on the (111)-one-VO, (111)-all-VO, (111)-33%-H and (110)-33%-H surfaces, the energy barriers of H2O formation are 1.55, 0.83, 1.19, and 1.28 eV respectively. Thus, the formation rate of H2O affects the regeneration of the oxygen vacancy and the rate of the catalytic cycle, and a too high energy barrier for the formation of H2O will severely limit the overall reaction rate. Furthermore, for the elementary step of H_In*+H_O* → H2O*, the (111)-one-VO surface also has the highest energy barrier of 1.06 eV, which is 0.29, 0.11 and 0.17 eV higher than those of the (111)-all-VO, (111)-33%-H, and (110)-33%-H surfaces. Therefore, the overall CO2 reaction rates of the (111)-all-VO, (111)-33%-H and (110)-33%-H surfaces are higher, so the formation of these surfaces during the induction phase of the CO2 reaction can lead to higher CO2 conversion rates. The predicted product selectivities are shown in Fig. 7(b) for the (111)-one-VO surface, where the methanol selectivity is greater than that of CO when the reaction temperature is below 352 °C, but the CO selectivity becomes higher at higher reaction temperatures. The RWGS reaction is endothermic, so increasing the reaction temperature is conducive to this reaction and will lead to high CO selectivity. Fig. 7(c) shows the predicted product selectivities for the other three surfaces, where only CO is produced. The low CO2 dissociation barriers on the (111)-33%-H (0.58 eV), (111)-all-VO (0.30 eV), and (110)-33%-H (0.80 eV) surfaces make CO formation on these surfaces very easy to occur, leading to exclusive CO formation. On the other hand, the energy barrier of methanol formation on the (111)-all-VO and (111)-33%-H surfaces of 1.14 and 1.54 are 0.84, and 0.96 eV higher than those of CO formation, making methanol formation on these surfaces less favorable. Therefore, if these three catalyst surfaces are formed during the induction period of the reaction, the methanol selectivity will be greatly reduced and more CO will be produced. The DRC value is a good indicator of the elementary reaction, which is positive for the elementary reaction, so stabilizing such a transition state should result in a higher reaction rate, whereas it is negative for the elementary reaction, and stabilizing such a transition state should lead to a lower reaction rate. CO is obtained by direct dissociation of CO2, and the elementary reaction for CO formation is bt-CO2* → CO* + O* for all the studied surfaces, and destabilizing this transition state will inhibit CO formation. On the (111)-one-VO surface (Fig. 7(d)), DRC values of H3CO*+H_O* → CH3OH*, HCOO* + H_In* → H2COO*, and H2* → H_In* + H_O* for methanol formation are positive, and stabilizing the transition states of these elementary reactions will accelerate methanol formation. On the (111)-all-VO surface (Fig. 7(e)), DRC values of H2CO* + H_In* +H_O* → H3CO* + H_O* for methanol formation are positive. On the (111)-33%-H surface (Fig. 7(f)), the DRC values for H2COO* → H2CO* + O* and H2* → H_In* + H_O* for methanol formation are positive, so the stabilizing the transition states of these two elementary reactions will promote methanol formation, while the DRC value of bt-CO2* → CO* + O* is negative for methanol formation, so stabilizing the transition state of this elementary reaction will not conducive to methanol formation. 3.5 Discussion The fresh In2O3 catalyst prepared by the precipitation method possesses a cubic In2O3 crystalline lattice structure with an average diameter of 7 nm relative uniform spherical particle morphology. Before the performance test in a feed gas with H2 and CO2, it was pretreated in an Ar flow at 300 °C for 1 h. This Ar pretreatment process can effectively promote the formation of thermal-induced oxygen vacancy on the In2O3 catalyst, and provide a stronger CO2 adsorpted surface, thus improve the CO2 hydrogenation efficiency. Though the thermally induced oxygen vacancy could be slowly created after the reaction was initiated at 300 °C without Ar pretreatment, the catalytic efficiency was lower and the induction stage was longer. With the increase of reaction temperature (220–300 °C) and pressure (1–5 MPa), the CO2 conversion and the methanol yield increase, this was confirmed by the experimental results as well as the reaction rates predicted from microkinetic simulations. Though the formation of VO is more difficult on the (111)-one-VO surface which has a higher energy barrier of H2O formation than the (111)-all-VO, (111)-33%-H and (110)-33%-H surfaces, the CO2 reaction rates increase with the rise of temperature on all the above four surfaces. However, the methanol selectivities decrease when the reaction temperature increases. This is because the methanol production is an exothermic reaction, while the by-product production of CO is an endothermic reaction. Due to the higher formation energy barrier of methanol than CO on the (111)-all-VO, (111)-33%-H and (110)-33%-H surfaces, the methanol production on these surfaces is less favorable; only the (111)-one-VO surface shows a greater methanol selectivity than of CO, but it has a lower reaction rate than the other three surfaces by three to five orders of magnitude. Previous studies have shown that on the (110)-all-VO surface, although the methanol selectivity is higher than that on the (110)-one-VO surface, the CO2 conversion rate is greatly reduced, which significantly reduces the methanol productivity [77]. In the induction stage, the proportion of these surfaces changes with the extension of reaction time, leads the gradual increases of CO2 conversion, while the selectivity of methanol gradually decreases until equilibrium is reached. The XRD, TEM, and N2 adsorption-desorption characterizations revealed significant sintering of the initially prepared small In2O3 particles after only 1 hour in the feeding gas at 300 °C, and the average diameter of the fresh In2O3 particles increases from ~7 to ~20 nm with a significant decrease of the In2O3 surface area from ~130 to ~30 m2 g–1 after 10 h of the reaction. This will result in a significant change in the active surface composition of the In2O3 catalyst. The CO2 conversion rate did not decrease upon the sintering of the In2O3 particles and the reduction in the catalyst surface area. As the amounts of thermally-induced and hydrogen-induced oxygen vacancies increase during the induction stage, they contribute more to the performance improvement than the inhibitory effect of catalyst sintering. After the creation of more oxygen vacancies, the total number of effective active sites increased, and a stronger adsorption of CO2 occurred, leading to improved CO2 conversion efficiency. The XPS, CO2-TPD, H2-TPR, and Raman spectra confirmed the increase in the amount of surface oxygen vacancies on the In2O3 catalyst once the reaction started. Our DFT calculations further rationalize the nature of the active sites of the In2O3 catalyst arising from the induction stage and their relevant performance features. The induction stage corresponds to the dynamic evolution of the four different In2O3 surface models employed to simulate the catalyst surfaces with different coverages of oxygen vacancies. During the reaction induction stage, the dominant surface gradually evolved from the (111)-one-VO to the other three surfaces with higher VO and hydroxylated coverage. Compared with the (111)-all-VO, (111)-33%-H, and (110)-33%-H surfaces, the (111)-one-VO surface shows a lower efficiency. This was attributed to the significantly higher energy barrier for H₂O formation on the (111)-one-VO surface, which hinders the creation of VO sites and limits the overall reaction rate of CO2 hydrogenation at the beginning of the reaction. Once the reaction starts, the amount of surface oxygen vacancies of the In2O3 catalyst increases, and the (111)-all-VO, (111)-33%-H, and (110)-33%-H surfaces were formed gradually, leading to the enhanced CO₂ conversion rate. However, these surfaces primarily promote CO production over methanol, leading to a decrease in methanol selectivity. This induction stage for the In2O3 catalyst was particularly evident during the first hour of the reaction, gradually slowing down over the next 5 to 10 h, and the catalyst structure stabilized after 10–20 h of reaction, accounting for the gradual increase in the CO2 conversion and the slow decrease in the methanol selectivity of the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Based on the above theoretical simulation and experimental results, we can form a better understanding of the structural evolution of the In2O3 catalyst during the initial induction and activation stage of the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. These physical insights into the performance of the In2O3 catalyst for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction should be valuable for the rational design of more efficient In2O3-based catalyst for this reaction. 4 Conclusions In this work, the induction period of the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over the In2O3 catalyst was investigated by experimental and computational methods. Nano-sized In2O3 materials prepared via the precipitation method were found to experience obvious sintering during the first 1 h of the reaction in the feed gas flow at 300 °C, whose size doubled compared to the initial average diameter of 7 nm, and continued to increase to about 20 nm after 5 h, and then stabilized. Though the induction stage leads to the decrease in the specific surface area of In2O3, more oxygen vacancies were created due to hydrogen reduction, which enhanced the performance of In2O3 for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. It was further confirmed by DFT calculations and microkinetic simulations that, during the induction period, an increase in the oxygen vacancy concentration and surface hydroxylation on In2O3 leads to higher CO2 conversion, accompanied by a reduction in methanol selectivity. This work thus provides a detailed observation and analysis of the changes in catalyst structure in the initial stage of the reaction, and provides valuable guidance for the design and synthesis of more efficient In2O3-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: As one of the most important industrially viable methods for carbon dioxide (CO2) utilization, methanol synthesis serves as a platform for production of green fuels and commodity chemicals. For sustainable methanol synthesis, In2O3 is an ideal catalyst and has garnered significant attention. Herein, cubic In2O3 nanoparticles were prepared via the precipitation method and evaluated for CO2 hydrogenation to produce methanol. During the initial 10 h of reaction, CO2 conversion gradually increased, accompanied by a slow decrease of methanol selectivity, and the reaction reached equilibrium after 10-20 h on stream. This activation and induction stage may be attributed to the sintering of In2O3 nanoparticles and the creation of more oxygen vacancies on In2O3 surfaces. Further experimental studies demonstrate that hydrogen induction created additional oxygen vacancies during the catalyst activation stage, enhancing the performance of In2O3 catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation. Density functional theory calculations and microkinetic simulations further demonstrated that surfaces with higher oxygen vacancy coverages or hydroxylated surfaces formed during this induction period can enhance the reaction rate and increase the CO2 conversion. However, they predominantly promote the formation of CO instead of methanol, leading to reduced methanol selectivity. These predictions align well with the above-mentioned experimental observations. Our work thus provides an in-depth analysis of the induction stage of the CO2 hydrogenation process on In2O3 nano-catalyst, and offers valuable insights for significantly improving the CO2 reactivity of In2O3-based catalysts while maintaining long-term stability.
